section.title: Matrices and Linear Transformations
section.introduction: Recall that every matrix transformation \vec{x} \mapsto A\vec{x} is a linear transformation. It turns out that also, every linear transformation T from \mathbb{R}^n to \mathbb{R}^m can be written as a matrix transformation. In other words, every linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^m can be written in the form T(\vec{x}) = A\vec{x} for some m \times n matrix A. Intuitively, the matrix A is the numerical formula which allows for concrete computation of the images T(\vec{x}).

subsection.title: Linear Transformations and Matrices
subsection.p:
Consider a linear transformation in the plane, T: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2. Notice that for any vector \vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^2, \vec{x} = (x_1, x_2), it can be written as a linear combination of the columns of the identity matrix I_2, which we will denote by \vec{e}_1 and \vec{e}_2. That is,
\vec{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \qquad \vec{e}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}
Then,
\vec{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} = x_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + x_2 \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = x_1 \vec{e}_1 + x_2 \vec{e}_2
Then, consider the image of \vec{x} under T,
T(\vec{x}) = T(x_1 \vec{e}_1 + x_2 \vec{e}_2)
By linearity, this is equivalent to,
T(\vec{x}) \amp = T(x_1 \vec{e}_1 + x_2 \vec{e}_2) \amp = x_1 T(\vec{e}_1) + x_2 T(\vec{e}_2)
Thus, if we know the images T(\vec{e}_1) and T(\vec{e}_2), we can determine T(\vec{x}). In this way, the transformation T is completely determined by the two images T(\vec{e}_1) and T(\vec{e}_2). Intuitively, if you know T(\vec{e}_1) and T(\vec{e}_2), then you know T.
Further, the transformation T can also be written as a matrix-vector product,
T(\vec{x}) \amp = x_1 T(\vec{e}_1) + x_2 T(\vec{e}_2) T(\vec{x}) \amp = \begin{bmatrix} T(\vec{e}_1) \amp T(\vec{e}_2) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}
Here, the matrix \begin{bmatrix} T(\vec{e}_1) \amp T(\vec{e}_2) \end{bmatrix} has two columns, given by the images of the vectors \vec{e}_1 and \vec{e}_2. If we denote this matrix by A, then the equation becomes,
T(\vec{x}) = A\vec{x}
That is, we have written T(\vec{x}) as a matrix transformation. Notice that the matrix A only depends on the transformation T, and not on the input vector \vec{x}. This can be generalized to a linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^m.
Intuitively, the term linear transformation focusses on the properties of the mapping, whereas matrix transformation describes how the mapping is implemented.

subsection.title: Linear Transformations and Linear Systems
subsection.p: The framework of linear transformation provides yet another perspective on linear systems.
